summaries.content: This document serves as the introduction and table of contents for a publication titled 'Fact Sheets on the European Union: The EU legal system and decision-making procedures' (PE 618.970). The fact sheets, compiled by the European Parliament's Policy Departments, cover key areas including sources of EU law, the principle of subsidiarity, and various decision-making and budgetary procedures. The publication, completed in June 2018, authorizes non-commercial reproduction provided the source is acknowledged.

The European Union possesses its own legal personality and a legal order distinct from international law, which has direct or indirect effect on the laws of its Member States. The EU legal order is hierarchically structured, primarily divided into primary legislation (Treaties, general principles, and the Charter of Fundamental Rights) and subordinate secondary legislation. Primary legislation holds the highest rank, with secondary legislation being valid only if consistent with these superior acts.

The legal acts of the Union, listed in Article 288 TFEU (regulations, directives, decisions, recommendations, and opinions), are subject to the principle of conferral outlined in Article 5(1) TEU. The TFEU categorizes these Union competences into exclusive (Article 3), shared (Article 4), and supporting (Article 6). While institutions generally use Article 288 TFEU instruments, the common foreign, security and defense policies are an exception, relying on 'general guidelines' and 'decisions defining' actions detailed in Article 25 TEU.

Articles 289, 290, and 291 TFEU establish a hierarchy of EU secondary legislation, comprising legislative acts, delegated acts, and implementing acts. Legislative acts are adopted through standard procedures, while delegated acts are non-legislative tools used to supplement existing legislation, with the power often delegated to the Commission by the Parliament and Council. Implementing acts are usually adopted by the Commission to ensure uniform application of laws, although the Council handles them in justified specific cases, notably in common foreign and security policy.

The text outlines the characteristics of EU Regulations and Directives. Regulations are fully binding, directly applicable across all Member States upon entry into force, and require no national transposition, ensuring uniform legal application. Directives, conversely, are binding only regarding the result to be achieved, granting national authorities discretion over the methods; they must be transposed into national law via implementing measures within a specified period.

Although directives are generally not directly applicable, the CJEU allows for exceptional direct effects (vertical effect) against public authorities if the provisions are imperative, clear, precise, and confer rights on individuals, provided the directive has not been transposed or was transposed incorrectly. However, directives cannot be invoked against other private individuals (no horizontal effect, established in Faccini Dori). Furthermore, the Francovich case established that individuals are entitled to seek compensation from a Member State for loss resulting from non-transposition, provided the directive intended to confer rights, the rights are identifiable, and a causal link exists.

To establish a Member State's liability for damages resulting from a failure to transpose a directive, three conditions must be met: the directive must confer identifiable rights on individuals, and there must be a causal link between the breach and the damage suffered; notably, proving fault on the part of the Member State is not required. The text also covers other EU legal acts: Decisions are binding in their entirety and may be directly applicable, though individuals can only invoke rights from a decision addressed to a Member State if a transposing act exists. Recommendations and opinions are non-binding, serving only as guidance for interpreting Union law.

The adoption of EU legislation involves the Parliament, the Council, and the Commission, with Parliament holding the right to ask the Commission to present legislative proposals. Enforcement of EU law is primarily carried out by Member States, who must adopt necessary national measures according to Article 291(1) TFEU; however, the Commission exercises implementing powers when uniform conditions are needed (Article 291(2) TFEU). Furthermore, when Treaties do not specify the type of legal act required, Article 296(1) TFEU mandates that institutions select the appropriate act on a case-by-case basis while respecting the principle of proportionality.

The general principles of Union law, including concepts like legal certainty and institutional balance, were primarily developed through the case-law of the Court of Justice of the European Union, which also formed the basis for recognizing fundamental rights as general principles. These principles are now formally enshrined in Article 6(3) TEU, referencing the ECHR, common constitutional traditions, and the Charter of Fundamental Rights. Additionally, the EU has the competence under Article 216(1) TFEU to conclude international agreements, which are binding on both the Union and its Member States and constitute an integral part of Union law.

Under Article 14(1) TEU, the European Parliament jointly exercises legislative and budgetary functions with the Council, utilizing the ordinary legislative procedure and a special procedure under Article 314 TFEU, respectively. The Parliament actively participates in creating new laws by examining the Commission's Annual Programme, and it also works to improve the quality of legal texts and impose effective penalties on non-compliant Member States. Furthermore, the consent of the European Parliament is mandatory for international agreements concerning the common commercial policy and policies falling under the ordinary legislative procedure.

The principle of subsidiarity governs the exercise of EU competences in areas where the Union does not have exclusive authority, defining when action is preferable at the Union level rather than by Member States. It safeguards the ability of Member States to act, authorizing Union intervention only when objectives cannot be sufficiently achieved nationally but can be better met at the Union level due to the scale and effects of the proposed action. Legally based on Article 5(3) TEU, this principle also ensures that powers are exercised as close to the citizen as possible, aligning with the proximity principle.

The principle of subsidiarity was formally enshrined by the Maastricht Treaty, although the Single European Act (1987) had already incorporated an implicit subsidiarity criterion into environmental policy. Before the TEU entered into force, the Court of First Instance ruled in 1995 that subsidiarity was not a general principle of law against which Community action could be tested. Subsequently, the Treaty of Amsterdam annexed a protocol that made the 1992 Edinburgh European Council approach to subsidiarity legally binding and subject to judicial review.

The Lisbon Treaty formally integrated the principle of subsidiarity into Article 5(3) TEU, highlighting its regional and local dimension. It also instituted Protocol No 2, replacing the 1997 protocol, which notably enhanced the role of national parliaments in ensuring compliance. The principle of subsidiarity is defined as guaranteeing independence for lower authorities relative to higher bodies, facilitating the sharing of powers across different levels of government.

When applied in the European Union, the principle of subsidiarity governs the exercise of non-exclusive powers, precluding Union intervention if Member States can effectively handle the issue at a central, regional, or local level. Intervention is justified only if Member States cannot satisfactorily achieve the objectives and the action provides added value at the Union level. Under Article 5(3) TEU, the three preconditions for EU action are non-exclusive competence, necessity (objectives unattainable by MS), and added value (successful implementation by the Union).

The principle of subsidiarity applies across all EU institutions, holding particular importance for legislative procedures. The Lisbon Treaty significantly strengthened the monitoring of this principle by enhancing the roles of both national parliaments and the Court of Justice. Additionally, the Treaty introduced an explicit reference to the subnational dimension of the subsidiarity principle.

The subsidiarity principle now explicitly incorporates a subnational dimension, strengthening the role of the Committee of the Regions and potentially involving regional parliaments in the ex-ante 'early warning' mechanism. This mechanism mandates that national parliaments monitor draft legislative acts for compliance with subsidiarity, allowing them eight weeks to submit reasoned opinions. If these opinions meet the 'yellow card' threshold (typically one-third of the total votes, or one-quarter for acts concerning freedom, security, and justice), the institution that produced the draft must review the act and justify its decision to maintain, amend, or withdraw it.

The segment details the 'orange card' procedure, which applies in the context of the ordinary legislative procedure. This mechanism is triggered if a simple majority of national parliamentary votes challenge a proposal's compliance with the subsidiarity principle, and the Commission decides to maintain the proposal. The matter is then referred to the European Parliament and Council, who can reject the proposal at first reading, requiring a 55% majority in the Council or a majority of the votes cast in the European Parliament.

The text details the first three instances where the 'yellow card' mechanism was successfully used by national parliaments to challenge Commission proposals based on the subsidiarity principle between 2012 and 2016. The first yellow card, issued in May 2012 against the 'Monti II' proposal, led to the Commission withdrawing the draft. However, for the subsequent yellow cards issued in October 2013 (European Public Prosecutor's Office) and May 2016 (posting of workers), the Commission chose to maintain its proposals, arguing that they complied with the subsidiarity principle.

Compliance with the principle of subsidiarity is subject to retrospective judicial review by means of a legal action brought before the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU). While Union institutions enjoy wide discretion, the Court verifies if the legislator was entitled to conclude that the objective could be better achieved at the Union level, based on a detailed statement. Legal actions concerning subsidiarity may be brought by Member States (often on behalf of national parliaments) or the Committee of the Regions under specific consultation requirements.

The European Parliament was the instigator of the concept of subsidiarity, proposing key provisions within the draft TEU adopted on 14 February 1984. This proposal stipulated that Member States could act in areas of concurrent competence until the Union legislated, reinforcing the idea that the Community should only intervene when tasks could be achieved more effectively in common. The Parliament consistently supported the principle of subsidiarity through various subsequent resolutions.

On October 25, 1993, the Council, Parliament, and the Commission signed an interinstitutional agreement demonstrating their commitment to the principle of subsidiarity. This agreement established procedures governing the application of the principle to arrange how the institutions exercise their Treaty-conferred powers. All three institutions undertook the responsibility to comply with and show that the principle of subsidiarity has been observed within their respective mandates.

The three EU institutions agreed to regularly check proposed actions for compliance with the principle of subsidiarity, covering both the substance and the choice of instruments. This monitoring is formalized internally, notably through Rule 42 of Parliament's Rules of Procedure and the Commission's annual subsidiarity report, which Parliament reviews. Furthermore, the 2016 Interinstitutional Agreement on 'Better Lawmaking' requires the Commission to justify subsidiarity in its explanatory memoranda and impact assessments, and Parliament and the Commission cooperate with national parliaments to facilitate their scrutiny role.

The European Parliament (EP) has consistently addressed the principle of subsidiarity through resolutions, declaring it a binding legal principle in 1997 while insisting it should not obstruct the EU's exclusive competence or challenge the acquis communautaire. Furthermore, in 2003, Parliament advocated for settling subsidiarity disputes politically and supported the proposed 'early warning' mechanism for national parliaments, which was subsequently incorporated into the Lisbon Treaty.

The European Parliament's 2012 resolution welcomed greater involvement of national parliaments in scrutinizing legislative proposals for compliance with subsidiarity and proportionality, suggesting investigations into easing participation barriers and setting EU-level compliance criteria. The text then transitions to defining supranational decision-making, explaining that EU Member States transfer powers to EU institutions, allowing them to make binding decisions across legislative, executive, budgetary, appointment, and quasi-constitutional procedures, an authority structure initially established by the Treaty of Rome.

The powers of the European Parliament have expanded progressively through successive treaty reforms, beginning with the 1970 and 1975 reforms that increased its role in the budgetary domain. Major developments include the Treaty of Maastricht introducing codecision with the Council, and the Treaties of Amsterdam and Nice extending codecision to new areas and granting Parliament powers equal to Member States in referring matters to the Court of Justice. The Treaty of Lisbon marked a further qualitative step towards achieving full equality with the Council in EU legislative and financial matters.

The Ordinary Legislative Procedure (OLP), formerly known as the codecision procedure, was significantly expanded by the Lisbon Treaty, adding 40 legal bases, particularly in justice, freedom, security, and agriculture, resulting in 85 total legal bases where Parliament and Council decide on equal footing. While the procedure follows steps like a Commission proposal and first readings in Parliament (simple majority) and Council (QMV), important areas such as fiscal policy concerning direct taxation or transnational family law remain excluded, requiring Council unanimity.

The ordinary legislative procedure includes specific procedural brakes for proposals concerning social security and police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. A single Member State can request that a proposal be submitted to the European Council (Articles 48 and 82 TFEU), suspending the procedure for a maximum of four months. Separately, if the Council approves Parliament's position, the legislative act is adopted immediately in the wording provided by Parliament.

The second reading stage outlines the decisions the European Parliament and the Council must take after the Council adopts its first reading position. The Parliament has three months to either approve the Council's text (adopting the act), reject it by an absolute majority (ending the procedure), or adopt amendments by an absolute majority. If Parliament amends the text, the Council then reviews these amendments, needing a qualified majority (or unanimity if the Commission opposed the amendment) within three months for the act to be adopted; otherwise, the Conciliation Committee is convened within six weeks.

The Conciliation phase involves a Committee of equal Council and Parliament representatives, assisted by the Commission, which must agree on a joint text within six weeks using specific majorities. If successful, the joint text moves to the third reading, where both the Council (by qualified majority) and Parliament (by majority of votes cast) must approve the text within another six weeks for the legislative act to be adopted. Failure to approve the text at either the conciliation or third reading stage halts the procedure and the act is not adopted.

This segment details the Consultation and Consent legislative procedures. The Consultation procedure mandates the Council to seek Parliament's opinion before deciding, noting that failure to consult makes an act illegal and subject to annulment. The Consent procedure, expanded by the Lisbon Treaty, requires Parliament's approval for significant areas, including EU membership, action against discrimination, the budgetary flexibility clause, and various international agreements like association agreements and accession to the ECHR.

The analyzed text details the final stage of the Consent Procedure, where Parliament must approve (but cannot amend) a draft act forwarded by the Council by an absolute majority of votes cast, although it is informally involved in prior stages. The segment also outlines key EU appointment procedures, noting that Parliament elects the President of the Commission and the European Ombudsman, while the Council and European Council handle appointments for the High Representative, other Commissioners, and members of bodies like the Court of Auditors and consultative committees.

facts.content: The publication is titled 'FACT SHEETS ON THE EUROPEAN UNION: The EU legal system and decision-making procedures'.
The publication identifier is PE 618.970.
The publication was authored by the European Parliament and completed in June 2018.
The Fact Sheets were compiled by Parliament's Policy Departments and Economic Governance Support Unit.

The publication covers the following topics: Sources and scope of European Union law, The principle of subsidiarity, Supranational decision-making procedures, Intergovernmental decision-making procedures, and The budgetary procedure.
Reproduction and translation for non-commercial purposes are authorized, provided the source is acknowledged and the publisher is given prior notice and sent a copy.
The European Union has legal personality and its own legal order, which is separate from international law.
EU law has direct or indirect effect on the laws of its Member States and becomes part of their legal systems.
The EU legal order is typically divided into primary legislation, secondary legislation, and supplementary law.
The Treaties on European Union (TEU) and the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) are sources of EU law.
The Treaty Establishing the European Atomic Energy Community (Euratom) is still in force as a separate treaty.
Primary legislation, consisting of the Treaties and general principles, is at the top of the hierarchy of Union law.

Following the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty on 1 December 2009, the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union was given the same value as the Treaties, making it part of primary legislation.
International agreements concluded by the European Union are subordinate to primary legislation.
The legal acts of the Union are listed in Article 288 TFEU and include regulations, directives, decisions, recommendations, and opinions.
The limits of Union competences are governed by the principle of conferral, which is enshrined in Article 5(1) TEU.
The TFEU defines Union competences, dividing them into three categories: exclusive competences (Article 3), shared competences (Article 4), and supporting competences (Article 6).
In the absence of necessary powers to attain an objective set out in the Treaties, institutions may apply Article 352 TFEU to adopt appropriate measures.

The common foreign, security and defence policies are exceptions to the use of legal acts listed in Article 288 TFEU, instead using 'general guidelines' and 'decisions defining' actions as per Article 25 TEU.
A hierarchy of secondary legislation is established by Articles 289, 290, and 291 TFEU, covering legislative acts, delegated acts, and implementing acts.
Legislative acts are legal acts adopted through the ordinary or a special legislative procedure.
Delegated acts are non-legislative acts of general application which supplement or amend certain non-essential elements of a legislative act.
The power to adopt delegated acts may be delegated to the Commission by the legislator (Parliament and the Council).
The legislative act defines the objectives, content, scope, and duration of the delegation of power for delegated acts.
The legislator lays down conditions for delegation, which may include the authority to revoke the delegation or the right to express an objection.
Implementing acts are generally adopted by the Commission when uniform conditions for implementing legally binding acts are needed.
The Council adopts implementing acts only in specific, duly justified cases and in areas of common foreign and security policy.

If a basic act was adopted under the ordinary legislative procedure, the European Parliament or the Council may indicate to the Commission that a draft implementing act goes beyond the implementing powers provided for in the basic act.
If the European Parliament or the Council indicates that a draft implementing act exceeds its powers, the Commission must revise the draft act.
Regulations are of general application, binding in their entirety and directly applicable.

Regulations are directly applicable in all the Member States as soon as they enter into force (on the date stipulated or, failing this, on the twentieth day following their publication in the Official Journal of the European Union).
Regulations do not need to be transposed into national law.
Regulations supersede national laws incompatible with their substantive provisions.
Directives are binding, as to the result to be achieved, upon any or all of the Member States to whom they are addressed.
Directives leave to the national authorities the choice of form and methods for implementation.
National legislators must adopt a transposing act or 'national implementing measure' to transpose directives.
Transposition of a directive must be effected within the period laid down in the directive.
In transposing directives, Member States guarantee the effectiveness of EU law, in accordance with the principle of sincere cooperation established in Article 4(3) TEU.
In principle, EU directives are not directly applicable.

The Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) has ruled that certain provisions of a directive may, exceptionally, have direct effects in a Member State even if the Member State has not yet adopted a transposing act.

For a directive to have exceptional direct effects, the directive must not have been transposed or must have been transposed incorrectly; the provisions must be imperative, sufficiently clear and precise; and the provisions must confer rights on individuals.
If the conditions for direct effect are met, individuals may invoke the directive provision in their dealings with public authorities (Vertical Direct Effect).
An individual may not rely on the direct effect of an untransposed directive in dealings with other individuals (the 'horizontal effect').
The principle denying horizontal effect for untransposed directives was established in the Faccini Dori Case (C-91/92).
According to the Francovich case (joined cases C-6/90 and C-9/90), an individual citizen is entitled to seek compensation from a Member State which is not complying with Union law.

Compensation for non-transposition of a directive is possible where the directive is intended to confer rights on individuals, the content of the rights can be identified, and there is a causal link between the breach of the obligation to transpose and the loss suffered by the injured parties.

Liability for a Member State's failure to transpose a directive is established if the directive was intended to confer rights on individuals, the content of the rights is identifiable, and there is a causal link between the breach and the loss suffered.
Fault on the part of the Member State does not have to be demonstrated to establish liability for damages resulting from the failure to transpose a directive.
Decisions are binding in their entirety.
Decisions may be directly applicable on the same basis as directives.
An individual may invoke the rights conferred by a decision addressed to a Member State only if that Member State has adopted a transposing act.
Recommendations and opinions do not confer any rights or obligations on those to whom they are addressed.
Parliament, the Council, and the Commission take part in the adoption of the Union's legislation to varying degrees.
Parliament can ask the Commission to present legislative proposals to itself and to the Council.
Under primary law, the EU has only limited powers of enforcement, as EU law is usually enforced by the Member States.
Article 291(1) TFEU states that Member States shall adopt all measures of national law necessary to implement legally binding Union acts.

The requirement to state reasons regarding subsidiarity compliance is met if it is clear from reading the recitals that the principle has been complied with.
Legal actions regarding subsidiarity compliance may be brought by Member States or notified by them on behalf of their national parliament or a chamber thereof.
The Committee of the Regions may bring actions against legislative acts regarding subsidiarity if the TFEU provides that it must be consulted on the adoption of such acts.
The European Parliament was the instigator of the concept of subsidiarity.
On 14 February 1984, the European Parliament adopted the draft TEU.
The European Parliament proposed a provision in the draft TEU stating that Member States could act in cases of concurrent competence as long as the Union had not legislated.
The European Parliament stressed that the Community should only act to carry out those tasks which could be undertaken more effectively in common than by individual states acting separately.
The Council, the European Parliament, and the Commission signed an interinstitutional agreement on October 25, 1993.
The 1993 interinstitutional agreement committed the three institutions to comply with the principle of subsidiarity.
The agreement lays down procedures governing the application of the principle of subsidiarity.
The Commission undertook to take into account the principle of subsidiarity and show that it has been observed.
Parliament and the Council undertook to observe the principle of subsidiarity within the context of the powers conferred on them.
The three EU institutions agreed to regularly use their internal procedures to check whether proposed action complies with the principle of subsidiarity.

Rule 42 of the European Parliament's Rules of Procedure requires Parliament to pay particular attention to whether a proposal for a legislative act respects the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality.
The European Commission produces an annual report on compliance with the subsidiarity principle.
The European Parliament usually gives its opinion on the Commission's annual subsidiarity report in the form of an own-initiative report drawn up by its Committee on Legal Affairs.

Under the Interinstitutional Agreement on ‘Better Lawmaking' of April 2016, the European Commission must explain in its explanatory memoranda how proposed measures are justified in light of the principle of subsidiarity.

Under the framework agreement of 20 November 2010, the European Parliament and the Commission undertook to cooperate with the national parliaments to facilitate their exercise of power to scrutinise compliance with the principle of subsidiarity.
In its resolution of 13 May 1997, the European Parliament stated that the principle of subsidiarity was a binding legal principle.
The European Parliament's 1997 resolution held that the implementation of the subsidiarity principle should not obstruct the exercise by the EU of its exclusive competence.
The European Parliament's 1997 resolution warned that the subsidiarity principle should not be used as a pretext to call into question the acquis communautaire.
In its resolution of 8 April 2003, the European Parliament suggested that disputes regarding subsidiarity should preferably be settled at the political level.
The Convention on the Future of Europe proposed the establishment of an ‘early warning' mechanism for national parliaments in the area of subsidiarity.
The ‘early warning' mechanism for national parliaments regarding subsidiarity was incorporated into the Lisbon Treaty.

In its resolution of 13 September 2012, the European Parliament welcomed the closer involvement of national parliaments in scrutinizing legislative proposals regarding subsidiarity and proportionality.
EU institutions make supranational binding decisions in legislative, executive, budgetary, appointment, and quasi-constitutional procedures.
The Treaty of Rome gave the Commission powers of proposal and negotiation, mainly in the fields of legislation and external economic relations.
The Treaty of Rome allocated powers for decision-making to the Council or representatives of the Member States' governments (in the case of appointments).
The Treaty of Rome gave the European Parliament a consultative power.
Parliament's role in the budgetary domain grew with the reforms of 1970 and 1975.
The Single European Act gave Parliament the power to authorise ratification of accession and association treaties.
The Treaty of Maastricht introduced codecision with the Council.
The Treaty of Amsterdam strengthened Parliament's role in appointing the Commission.
The Treaty of Nice applied the codecision procedure to almost all new areas where the Council was entitled to decide by qualified majority.
The Treaty of Nice granted Parliament the same powers as the Member States in terms of referring matters to the Court of Justice.
The Treaty of Lisbon represents a step towards full equality with the Council in EU legislation and finance.
The Ordinary Legislative Procedure (OLP) was formerly called the codecision procedure.
The Lisbon Treaty added 40 further legal bases to the Ordinary Legislative Procedure, notably in justice, freedom, security, and agriculture.
The Ordinary Legislative Procedure now applies to 85 legal bases.
The Ordinary Legislative Procedure includes Qualified Majority Voting (QMV) in the Council.
During the first reading of the Ordinary Legislative Procedure, Parliament adopts its position by a simple majority.
Areas like fiscal policy concerning direct taxation or transnational aspects of family law are excluded from the Ordinary Legislative Procedure and require unanimity in the Council.

In the fields of social security and police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, a legislative proposal can be submitted to the European Council at the request of one Member State (Articles 48 and 82 TFEU).
The submission of a proposal to the European Council suspends the ordinary legislative procedure for up to four months, until the European Council reassigns the matter to the Council.
Under Article 82 TFEU, at least nine Member States may decide to continue deliberations under enhanced cooperation (Article 20 TEU and Article 326-334 TFEU).
If the Council approves Parliament's position during the ordinary legislative procedure, the legislative act is adopted in the wording which corresponds to Parliament's position.
During the second reading of the Ordinary Legislative Procedure, the European Parliament has three months to decide on the Council's position.
If the European Parliament rejects the Council's position during the second reading, it must do so by an absolute majority of its Members, resulting in the procedure ending.
To adopt amendments to the Council's position during the second reading, the European Parliament requires an absolute majority of its Members.
The Council votes on Parliament's second reading amendments by a qualified majority, but requires unanimity if the Commission has delivered a negative opinion on those amendments.
If the Council fails to approve all of Parliament's second reading amendments within three months, the Conciliation Committee must be convened within six weeks.
The Conciliation Committee consists of an equal number of Council and Parliament representatives, assisted by the Commission.
The Conciliation Committee has six weeks to agree on a joint text.
Agreement on a joint text in the Conciliation Committee requires a Qualified Majority Vote (QMV) of Council representatives and a majority of Parliament's representatives.
In the conclusion of the procedure (third reading), the Council and Parliament have six weeks to approve the joint text.
The Council acts by a qualified majority when approving the joint text during the conclusion of the procedure.
Parliament acts by a majority of the votes cast when approving the joint text during the conclusion of the procedure.
Some bridge clauses allow the European Council to extend the application of the ordinary procedure to areas exempted from it, such as social policy (Article 153(2)).
Under the Consultation procedure, the Council must take note of the opinion of Parliament before taking a decision.
The absence of mandatory consultation with Parliament makes an EU act illegal and capable of annulment by the Court of Justice.
If the Council intends to substantially amend a proposal, it is required to consult Parliament again (judgment in Case 65/90).
The scope of the Consent procedure was expanded following the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty.
The Consent procedure applies to the horizontal budgetary flexibility clause (Article 352 TFEU).
Parliament's consent is required for EU membership (Articles 49 and 50 TEU) and action to combat discrimination (Article 19(1) TFEU).
Parliament's consent is required for association agreements (Article 217 TFEU) and the accession of the Union to the ECHR (Article 6(2) TEU).
Under the Consent Procedure, Parliament decides whether to approve a draft act by an absolute majority of the votes cast.
Under the Consent Procedure, Parliament cannot amend the draft act forwarded by the Council.
Parliament elects the President of the Commission (Article 14(1) TEU).
The European Council appoints the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, acting by qualified majority (Article 18(1) TEU).
The Council adopts the list of other persons proposed for appointment as Members of the Commission by qualified majority, in common accord with the President-elect (Article 17(7) TEU).
The Council adopts the list of members of the Court of Auditors after consulting Parliament and based on proposals put forward by the Member States (Article 286 TFEU).
Parliament elects the European Ombudsman (Article 228 TFEU).
Having gained legal personality, the Union can now conclude international agreements.
